initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?
stories: My observation is that there exists an unequal distribution of state monies among its residents. Before urban residents get defensive, please hear me out. Currently, only corporations pay state income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state-funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct docks, powerful politicians' pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers, and other services. All of these expenses and more are unnecessary within city limits. I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities, which in turn increases the state budget. Last night, on television, I saw how ADG&G was teaching the little ones how to ice fish. Couldn't the parents do that? Yes, I pay property taxes. However, I guarantee you that once our city folk receive the full bill without state monies, they will become more frugal. Regarding the office building, I suggest renting only the required space to help the office rental market. In my previous business, I would ask my managers, "How can we stop spending money?"

I was shocked when I received a text message from the state government. The message informed me that my observation about the unequal distribution of state monies among its residents had been accepted as part of a study. The message also asked me to continue the text, to provide my thoughts and opinions on the matter.

I pondered the issue for a moment, wondering how I could contribute to the study. I had noticed that state-funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct docks, and powerful politicians' pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers, and other services were all unnecessary within city limits. I had seen how these expenses and more increased the state budget, and I believed that city folk should be more frugal once they received the full bill without state monies.

I decided to focus on the issue of the office building. I had noticed that the state government had rented a large office building in the city, and I believed that this was unnecessary. I suggested that the state government should rent only the required space to help the office rental market.

I also suggested that the state government should provide more funding for the education system in rural areas. I believed that this would help to reduce the unequal distribution of state monies among its residents, and that it would help to provide more opportunities for those who lived in rural areas.

I hoped that my thoughts and opinions would be taken into consideration, and that the state government would take steps to reduce the unequal distribution of state monies among its residents. I believed that this was an important issue, and that it needed to be addressed in order to ensure that everyone in the state had access to the same opportunities and resources.

Once upon a time, there was a young girl named Alice who lived in a small town. One day, she stumbled upon a strange book in her local library that seemed to be written in a language she had never seen before.

As she flipped through the pages, she became more and more intrigued by the mysterious symbols and patterns she saw. She had always been fascinated by languages and puzzles, so she decided to take the book home with her to study further.

For days, Alice pored over the book, trying to decipher its meaning. She had no idea what language it was, but she was determined to figure it out. She tried different translation tools and online resources, but nothing seemed to work.

Finally, after weeks of frustration, Alice had an idea. She decided to create her own language, inspired by the symbols and patterns she had seen in the book. She spent hours crafting each letter and symbol, and eventually she had a complete alphabet.

Excited by her progress, Alice began writing stories and poems in her new language. She even created a small dictionary and grammar guide to help others learn it.

Before long, Alice's language became known throughout her town, and people began to study it and use it in their own writing. Alice was thrilled to see her creation come to life and to watch as it inspired others to explore new forms of expression.

From that day on, Alice continued to study languages and create new ones of her own. She became a renowned linguist and was known for her unique approach to language and communication. But no matter how far she traveled or how many languages she learned, she always remembered her humble beginnings and the mysterious book that had started it all.

One day, she stumbled upon a strange book in her local library that seemed to be written in a language she had never seen before. As she flipped through the pages, she became more and more intrigued by the mysterious symbols and patterns she saw.

Alice had always been fascinated by languages and puzzles, so she decided to take the book home with her to study further. For days, she pored over the book, trying to decipher its meaning. She had no idea what language it was, but she was determined to figure it out.

Suddenly, a strange man appeared in front of her, carrying a large backpack. He introduced himself as a linguist and asked if he could help her with the book. Alice was hesitant at first, but she decided to take a chance and show him the book.

The linguist examined the book carefully, turning the pages and scrutinizing the symbols. After a few moments, he declared that the book was written in a language that had been lost for centuries. He explained that it was a language that had been spoken by a long-extinct civilization, and that he had been studying it for years in hopes of deciphering its secrets.

Alice was amazed by this discovery, and she asked the linguist if he could teach her the language. The linguist agreed, and for weeks, they studied together, learning the intricacies of the lost language.

As Alice became more proficient in the language, she began to see patterns and meanings in the symbols that had eluded her before. She discovered that the book was actually a collection of ancient poems and stories, written in the language of the lost civilization.

With the help of the linguist, Alice was able to translate the book, and she became fascinated by the culture and beliefs of the people who had spoken the language. She decided to continue studying the language and the culture, and eventually, she became an expert in the field.

From that day on, Alice dedicated her life to studying languages and cultures, and she became known as one of the world's foremost experts in ancient civilizations. But no matter how far she traveled or how many languages she learned, she always remembered the strange book that had started it all.
